questions.text: Mutation present in AML having blasts with 'cup-like' nuclear invaginations
questions.solution: • Presence of cup-like or fish-mouth-like nuclear indentations in blasts of AML is associated with NPM1 and FLT3 gene mutations.

questions.text: Leukemia cutis is most commonly associated with
questions.solution: • Leukemia cutis develops when tumors with monocytic differentiation infiltrate the skin.

questions.text: Best prognosis in AML

choices.text: Transcription factor mutations that interfere with normal myeloid differentiation
Mutation of signaling proteins that result in constitutive activation of pro-growth/survival pathways
Mutations of gene that regulate or maintain epigenome

questions.text: All these are example of driver mutations in AML except
questions.solution:
• Different translocations and chromosomal rearrangements create chimeric genes that encode fusion proteins that interfere with transcription factors and bock maturation of myeloid cells.
  • AMLs with t(15;17) have activating mutations in FLT3, a receptor tyrosine kinase that transmits signals that mimic normal growth factor signaling
  • AMLs associated with IDH1 and IDH2 mutations that create oncometabolite 2-hydroxyglutarate affect epigenome.
  • Mutations of TP53 or genes that regulate p53 adds poor prognosis in AML

questions.text: MRP 2 associated with which of the following?
questions.solution: • Dubin-Johnson syndrome is an autosomal recessive disorder leading to impaired biliary excretion of bilirubinbin glucuronides due to mutation in canalicular multidrug resistance protein 2 (MRP2).

questions.text: 70 year old female presented with abdominal pain. She went for scan, and presented with honeycomb lesion in pancreas. which of the following is not true about the lesion described.
questions.solution: Serous cystic neoplasms are almost always benign, whereas others, such as intraductal papillary mucinous neoplasms and mucinous cystic neoplasms, are precancerous. Serous cystic neoplasms usually occur in the tail of the pancreas. The cysts are small (1 to 3 mm) and can be solitary, multiple, or present as a honeycomb of microcystic lesions. Serous cysts are lined by glycogen-rich cuboidal cells, and contain clear, thin, straw-colored fluid. They account for 15% to 25% of all cystic neoplasms of the pancreas and are twice as common in women. Serous cystic neoplasms typically present in the sixth to seventh decade of life with nonspecific symptoms such as abdominal pain, but many are detected incidentally during imaging for another indication. Surgical resection is curative in the vast majority of patients. Inactivation of the VHL tumor suppressor gene on chromosome 3p is the most common genetic abnormality in serous cystic neoplasms.

questions.text: which of the following changes are not seen on the Hematoxylin and Eosin stained section from the heart of a patient after myocardial infarction within 6 to 12 hours
questions.solution: The typical changes of coagulative necrosis become detectable in the first 6 to 12 hours. “Wavy fibers” may be present at the periphery of the infarct, resulting from the contractions of viable myocardium that cause the stretching and buckling of adjacent, noncontractile dead fibers. An additional sublethal ischemic change may be seen in the margins of infarcts: this so-called myocyte vacuolization reflects intracellular accumulations of salt and water within the sarcoplasmic reticulum, and marks myocytes that are viable but poorly contractile. Necrotic myocardium elicits acute inflammation (typically most prominent 1 to 3 days after MI), followed by a wave of macrophages that remove necrotic myocytes and neutrophil fragments (most pronounced 3 to 7 days after MI).

choices.text: Myxomatous degeneration and prolapse of the mitral valve
Fibrinous deposition on the tip of papillary muscle
Aschoff nodule on the mitral valve

questions.text: young female patient came for routine examination. On examination a mid-systolic click was found. There is no history of rheumatic heart disease. The histopathological examination is most likely to show which of the following?
questions.solution:
The important clues given in the ;

  • Female patient
  • Presenting for Routine examination (means she was asymptomatic)
  • Presence of mid systolic click on physical examination
  • Absence of history of rheumatic heart disease

All these are significant pointers towards a diagnosis of mitral valve prolapse or Barlow syndrome. The other name of the same condition is Myxomatous degeneration of the mitral valve. So, the answer is option 'a' Direct lines from Robbins 'Most patients with mitral valve prolapse are asymptomatic, and the condition is discovered only on routine examination by the presence of a mid-systolic click as an incidental finding on physical examination'

Concept

  • Commissural fusion that typifies rheumatic heart disease is absent in mitral valve prolapse.

questions.text: A 45 years old male had severe chest pain and was admitted to the hospital with a diagnosis of acute myocardial infraction. Four days later he died and autopsy showed transmural coagulative necrosis. Which of the following microscopic features will be seen on further examination?

A neoplasm is found within the cranial cavity. A histopathological examiantion is obtained and microscopic examination shows tumor cells within vascular lumina. Which of the following types of vessels is most likely to be invaded by this malignancy?
questions.solution: Veins have thin walls compared to their diameter and fewer layers. Its characteristics make them more prone to compression and invasion by malignancies. Hematogenous metastasis takes via this place. Of the remaining options, lymphatic invasion is an excellent choice, but the intracranial location chosen for this question excludes lymphatics, which are extracranial in the head. Neoplasms can secrete growth factors to promote endothelial proliferation and capillary formation to form a stromal vascular supply for continued growth.

questions.text: A 10-year old boy, pappu, died of acute rheumatic fever. All of the following can be expected at autopsy except:
questions.solution: Rupture of chordae tendinae is a feature of chronic rheumatic heart disease.

questions.solution: The Casal collar or Casal necklace is a clinical sign in which there is an erythematous pigmented skin rash in the distribution of a broad collar (dermatomes C3 and C4). It is seen in patients with pellagra. The sign is named after Gaspar Casal.

questions.text: Lynch syndrome is associated with cancer of the
questions.solution:
• Lynch syndrome is an autosomal dominant disorder
  • It is also called as Hereditary non- polyposis colon cancer (HPCC) syndrome
  • It is caused because of defective DNA repair genes leading to microsatellite instability
  • There is increased chance of multiple cancers (colorectal area, endometrium, ovary stomach, ureter, brain, small intestine, hepatobiliary tract and skin)

questions.text: A 58-year-old man has reported increasing fatigue over the past year. Laboratory studies show a serum creatinine level of 6.8 mg/dL and BUN of 56 mg/dL. An abdominal ultrasound scan shows that bilateral kidneys are atrophic symmetrically. The high-magnification appearance of the kidneys under LM is shown. These findings are most likely to indicate which of the following underlying conditions?
questions.solution: The image shows an arteriole with hyaline thickening of the vessel wall, indicative of hyaline arteriolosclerosis. Diabetes mellitus also can lead to this finding, which is most often seen in kidneys. DIC can lead to arteriolar thrombi. Amyloidosis presents with nephrotic syndrome. Syphilis can cause a vasculitis involving the vasa vasorum of the aorta.

questions.text: A 54-year-old man has had a fever, cough, and worsening shortness of breath for the past few days. On physical examination, his temperature is 39.2°C. Auscultation of the chest shows decreased breath sounds over all lung fields. A bronchoalveolar lavage is performed, and the fluid obtained is observed under a microscope. Image is attached. Laboratory studies show a CD4+ lymphocyte count of 100/μL; total serum globulin concentration of 2.5 g/dL; and WBC count of 6500/mm3 with 75% segmented neutrophils, 8% bands, 6% lymphocytes, 10% monocytes, and 1% eosinophils. Which of the following serologic laboratory findings is most likely to be positive in this patient?
questions.solution: Pneumocystis jiroveci pneumonia is a common finding in patients with AIDS. This patient's low CD4+ count is characteristic of AIDS, irrespective of total leukocyte counts. Antineutrophil cytoplasmic autoantibody can be seen in patients with vasculitis. Rheumatoid factor is present in most patients with rheumatoid arthritis. The antistreptolysin O titer is elevated in patients with rheumatic fever, but there is no serious immunosuppression. The ANA test result is positive in various autoimmune diseases, but a decrease in CD4+ count is not typical of such conditions.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman with a 10-year history of intravenous drug use has developed a chronic watery diarrhea that has been present for 5 days. On physical examination, she is afebrile and has mild muscle wasting. She has a BMI of 16. Laboratory studies of the stool show cysts of Cryptosporidium parvum. One month later, she develops cryptococcal meningitis, which is treated successfully. Oral candidiasis is diagnosed 1 month later. This patient is at greatest risk of developing which of the following neoplasms?
questions.solution: Opportunistic infections in an intravenous drug abuser suggest a diagnosis of HIV infection and possibly, full blown AIDS. The most common neoplasms seen in association with AIDS are B cell non-Hodgkin lymphoma and Kaposi sarcoma. A rare tumor associated with AIDS in children is leiomyosarcoma. Cervical dysplasias and carcinomas are increased in women with HIV infection, but are not as common as lymphoma. Lung cancers at this woman's age are uncommon in any condition. Opportunistic infections of the brain and central nervous system lymphomas are common in patients with AIDS, but glial neoplasms like astrocytomas are not.

questions.text: Activation of which transcription factor is responsible for growth of Reed-Sternberg cells

choices.text: Interact with eosinophils with CD30 on its surface

questions.text: True statement about Reed-Sternberg cells
questions.solution: • Reed-Sternberg cells express PD-L1 and PD-L2 that suppress Cytotoxic T cells response. Interact with eosinophils with CD30 and with T helper cells with CD40. Secrete M-CSF (Monocyte/macrophage-colony stimulating factor).
